I'm not following what the issue is. Could you please elaborate?

The node always starts mining on an empty block and then switches over to a full one in the background. Then periodically (every 3 secs by default) it reruns the transaction inclusion logic to get more/better ones in. Would this behavior explain what you're seeing?

@karalabe Thanks for your comment,

Here is my expected workflow for sealing transactions and it worked on previous geth version release

+ Geth version: 1.8.13 &  1.8.16
+ Operating system: Ubuntu 16.04 AWS
+ Installation: apt-get
+ Fully synchronized: yes
+ Network: Ropsten
+ Mining: Yes

### expected behavior / 1.8.13

geth receives transactions on txpool -> pick up the transactions and mining them til gas cap -> while old transactions are "still" waiting on txpool geth receives new transactions and mine them as a priority by gas fee

### actual behavior / 1.8.16

geth receives transactions on txpool -> pick up the transactions and mining them til gas cap -> **purge all transactions on local txpool when receives new block or mines new block** -> receiving new transactions on txpool

What I am concerned is geth does not save old transactions if it is not mined ( This happens on mining node only - doesn't happening on sync-only node )

**And this will create more empty blocks although there is ton of pending transactions on the other node**

Here is the gas limit usage on ropsten https://ropsten.etherscan.io/blocks and as you can see although there is 1000 pending transactions no one is mining them since it is being purged every block

The local transactions are not purged on receiving a new block.
I don't know if that used to be the behaviour 2 years ago, but it is not with the current release.
Since the user is ghost, I'll close the issue. You can reopen if this issue arises again
